item.title: Bash's find command
item.description:
The find command in bash is quite powerful, and knowing the basics might save you some scripting.

What does it do? It “finds” files. By default, it outputs their path relative to where you ran find. But, in addition of providing you with advanced “filters” it actually allows you to run commands on each of those files.

Let’s get started!

item.title: Change shell used to run external command
item.description: On windows, the cmd sucks. But if you have sh installed from git-for-windows for example, you can tell vim to run external commands :!. Add this to your .vimrc set shell=sh set shellcmdflag=-c Now, vim won’t run external commands like this cmd /c "your command" But like this: sh -c "your command" So, you can now run Unix commands from VIM. To learn more: :help 'shell'
